{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3003254,"name":"Noah Eckfeldt","username":"MachoStoopid","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/machostoopid/{size}/193796_2.png","created_at":"2022-02-05T05:09:15.844Z","cooked":"

Hey CD,

It’s as the title suggests, we are planning on using polycord on our robot this year and are curious about how the grip falls off over a prolonged distance. Right now we are doing 9-10 in long runs and are having moderate success. Where is your teams sweet spot for this material.

Thanks,
Noah E.
Skunkworks 1983

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2022-02-05T05:09:15.844Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":141,"readers_count":140,"score":68.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":402221,"topic_slug":"effectiveness-of-polycord-over-distances","display_username":"Noah Eckfeldt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33625,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Wanna be CAD god"},"post_url":"/t/effectiveness-of-polycord-over-distances/402221/1","custom_user_title":"Wanna be CAD god","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3003286,"name":"SndMndBdy","username":"SndMndBdy","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/13edae/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-02-05T12:31:03.768Z","cooked":"

In my experience, 9-10 inches is about the limit for how long of a run you can effectively use polycord on round object. The problem with longer runs is that in the middle, the cord is very unconstrained. Because the cord needs to have some tension on the ball, it tends to want to run down the side of the ball, rather than staying on its line. This causes the cord to have less tension on the ball (and do a worse job of moving it) or even coming off of its pulley.

This problem is experienced far less on flat objects, but that’s not what you are dealing with this year.

One alternative would be to use a flat belt. This is a common product that is used in FRC: Urethane Flat Belting - VEX Robotics

This work best when driven by a crowned roller, which helps keep the belt centered. See: How crowned pulleys keep a flat belt tracking

3D printers work well for making crowned rollers, if you have access to them. I’ve also seen teams make these by using a line of 3 wheels, with the one in the middle having a slightly bigger diameter. I have no personal experience with this approach, so I can’t totally vouch for it.
